titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Albert Lewin Papers PASC.0314
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Katie Richardson and Julie Graham, additions by Peggy Alexander, 2016; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√©.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-09-07 11:36:41 -0700.

did.abstract: Albert E. Lewin was a comedy writer whose career spanned from the 1930s to the 1990s. His numerous credits include a mixture of productions from radio, television, motion pictures, and stage. The collection consists of script and production files as well as small amount of business files, correspondence, sound recordings and printed material related to his career.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Audio materials in this collection are restricted and require advance notice for use.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Albert Lewin Papers (Collection PASC 314).UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Katie Richardson and Julie Graham. Additions processed by Peggy Alexander, 2016.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

odd.head: UCLA Catalog Record ID
odd.p: UCLA Catalog Record ID: 9960923663606533

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Albert E. Lewin was born on July 29, 1916 in New York City, New York. Lewin attended the Art Institute of Chicago and Los Angeles Valley College. He developed an early interest in comedy writing working as a cartoonist and comic artist for Colliers, Satevepost, and other magazines. He began writing for radio in 1938, writing jokes for Billy House's Wrigley Laughliner on the Columbia network. He contributed to radio programs working with a variety of talent including Don Ameche, Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy, Bing Crosby, Victor Borge, Tommy Riggs, Judy Canova, Ransom Sherman, Charles Ruggles, Carmen Miranda, Greer Garson, and Martha Raye among others. During World War II, Lewin served in the military and fought in France and Germany for five and a half months. He then served with the American Forces Network of the Armed Forces Radio Service where he wrote and directed programs with Mickey Rooney, Jack Benny, and Bob Hope. Following the war he continued working in radio contributing to shows such as The Eddie Cantor Show, The Chase and Sanborn Program, Scattergood Baines, and The Tommy Riggs Show, among others.

He had a prolific writing career for television including credits for the series Bob Hope Presents the Chrysler Theatre, The Brady Bunch, Diff'rent Strokes, Eddie Cantor Comedy Theatre, The Ghost and Mrs. Muir, The Good Guys, My Favorite Martian, and The Odd Couple, among others. Additionally, he was involved in made for TV movie productions including Coffee, Tea, or Me. His motion picture credits include Eight on the Lam, Alice in Wonderland, Wicked Dreams of Paula Schultz, I Will, I Will...For Now, and Boy, Did I Get a Wrong Number!, among others. Lewin also co-wrote two books including The Glass Bed and two plays including The Gift Horse. He often collaborated with Norman Panama and Burt Styler on writing projects. Albert E. Lewin died of congestive heart failure in Los Angeles, CA, on April 23, 1996, he was 79.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of materials documenting the career of comedy writer, Albert E. Lewin. Included in the collection are writings for radio, television, motion pictures, and stage projects as well as a book project in which Lewin was involved. Additionally, there is a small amount of business files, correspondence, sound recordings, printed material, and memorabilia from the 63rd Infantry Division, Lewin's former Army unit. The radio related writings include a mixture of complete and partial scripts, sketches, segments, and ideas for radio programs, such as the Armed Forces Radio Service productions featuring Bing Crosby and Edgar Bergen, The Chase and Sanborn Program, Play Broadcast, Scattergood Baines, and The Tommy Riggs Show, among others. The writings for motion picture projects include scripts along with a small quantity of production information for produced and unproduced film projects such as Alice in Wonderland, and I Will, I Will...For Now, among others. Of particular note are writings documenting Lewin's association with Bob Hope, including Boy, Did I Get a Wrong Number!, Eight on the Lam, and I'll Take Sweden. The book project writings contain files for The Glass Bed, a novel that was adapted from an unproduced motion picture screenplay by Lewin and Norman Panama titled Hollywood and Vine.

The television writings include a mixture of complete and partial scripts, notes, story ideas, monologues, outlines, treatments, and occasional production information for television features and episodic series such as Bob Hope Presents the Chrysler Theatre, The Brady Bunch, Diff'rent Strokes, The Eddie Cantor Comedy Theatre, Facts of Life, The Ghost an Mrs. Muir, and My Favorite Martian, among others. The stage projects' writings include a mixture of complete and partial play scripts, notes, and ideas for The Gift Horse and Trashman. Additionally, there is a small portion of unidentified writings believed related to motion picture, radio, television, or other projects for which the production status and Lewin's involvement are unknown and a gag file containing handwritten jokes or one-liners compiled and possibly written by Lewin.

Also included in the collection is a very small amount of fragmentary records documenting business dealings related to Lewin's career as well as small quantity of correspondence. There are a small number of home recorded cassette tapes and audio reels of meetings and/or phone conversations created by Lewin and related to a various projects in which he was involved. There are also press clippings mentioning Lewin or the projects he was involved. Additionally, the collection contains a small number of items relating to Lewin's service in the 63rd Infantry Division. Along with Lewin's papers are a holograph manuscript of a publication titled Little Billy Boat and a press clipping related to his wife, Esther Lewin.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Radio projects
Motion picture projects
Television projects
Stage productions
Gag files
Book projects
Unidentified projects
Business files
Correspondence
Printed materials
Sound recordings
63rd Infantry Division service
Esther Lewin papers

Television comedy writers -- United States -- Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Radio Projects series includes script materials for produced and what may be unproduced radio projects in which Lewin was involved in some capacity. The series is arranged alphabetically into subseries by known radio program or project titles. For unidentified radio material, the proccessor created the subseries, Unidentified Projects. The writings include a mixture of complete and partial scripts, sketches, segments, and ideas for radio programs, such as Armed Forces Radio Service productions featuring Bing Crosby and Edgar Bergen, among others, The Chase and Sanborn Program, Play Broadcast, Scattergood Baines, and The Tommy Riggs Show, among others. A portion of the file titles were created and/or enhanced by the processor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Motion Picture Projects series includes script materials and a small amount of production information for produced and what appear to be unproduced film projects in which Lewin was involved in some capacity. The series is arranged into a subseries alphabetically by project titles. The script material includes a mixture of complete and partial scripts and notes. Additionally, there are occasional shooting schedules, call sheets, and letters about productions found among the files. Projects include Alice in Wonderland and I Will, I Will...For Now, among others. Of particular note are scripts documenting Lewin's association with Bob Hope, including Boy, Did I Get a Wrong Number!, Eight on the Lam, and I'll Take Sweden. Additionally, there are materials for Hollywood and Vine, an unproduced work which was later adapted into the published novel, The Glass Bed. See also Book Projects for material related to The Glass Bed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Television Projects series contains script materials for produced and what may be unproduced television productions in which Lewin was involved in some capacity. The series is arranged alphabetically into subseries by project titles. The writings include a mixture of complete and partial scripts, notes, story ideas, monologues, outlines, treatments, and occasional production information for television features and episodic series. Projects in the series include Bob Hope Presents the Chrysler Theatre, The Brady Bunch, Coffee, Tea, or Me?, The Dennis Day Show, Diff'rent Strokes, The Eddie Cantor Comedy Theatre, Facts of Life, The Ghost an Mrs. Muir, The Good Guys, Green Acres, The Life of Riley, My Favorite Martian, The Odd Couple, and The Ray Milland Show, among others. The files within each subseries are arranged alphabetically by episode title or file titles which reflect the content of the folders. Unless otherwise noted, most files are scripts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Stage Productions series includes script materials for produced and what may be unproduced stage projects in which Lewin was involved in some capacity. The series is arranged alphabetically into subseries by project titles. The writings include a mixture of complete and partial playscripts, notes, and ideas for The Gift Horse and Trashman (which may also be known as The Big Sweat Over Swizel Mahoney). The files within each subseries are arranged alphabetically by file titles which reflect the content of the folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Gag Files series consists of jokes, gags, and/or one-liners handwritten on 3x5 index cards. The file was created by Lewin and is organized by topics and/or subjects. It appears that the file is in its original order; however, it is not clear how the topics are organized. Many of the topics appear to be divided into subject divisions related to the topic.

did.unittitle: Topical gags, jokes, and/or one liners written on 3x5 index cards
Topical gags, jokes, and/or one liners written on 3x5 index cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Book Projects series consists of materials relating to the novel that Lewin co-wrote with Norman Panama entitled, The Glass Bed. The series contains typescript manuscripts, reviews, publicity, and a small number of letters regarding the project. The Glass Bed is adapted from the motion picture screenplay by Lewin and Panama titled Hollywood and Vine. See also the Motion Pictures Series for material related to Hollywood and Vine. The series is arranged alphabetically by file titles which reflect the content of the folders.

odd.p: With agreement between Panama and Lewin and William Morrow & Co.

odd.p: With holograph notes.

odd.p: Holograph and typescript version of Answers- Questions about the new novel.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Working title for Glass Bed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Unidentified Projects series contains a mixture of partial and complete scripts, notes, idea, outlines, and a small number of letters all of which could be related to possible motion picture, radio, television, and/or other writing projects. The capacity in which Lewin was involved with these projects or if they were produced is unknown. Additionally, there are a small number of writings for what appears to be dinner speeches and roasts for politicians written in the 1970s. The files in the series are arranged alphabetically by project title.

did.unittitle: Charlie McCarthy and Edgar Bergen material

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Appears to be for radio.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Step outline, notes, and letters about the project.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Notes and drafts for what appears to be written remarks for others to present at political-type social events. Events appear to be for James Corman, Tony Bielenson, Ted Gutman, George McGovern.

did.unittitle: Show of Truth by Lewin and Styler.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Typescript manuscript.

did.unittitle: Wonderful Heel (The) book by Albert Lewin and Burt Styler

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Appears to be play script.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Business Files series contains a small amount of fragmentary records documenting business dealings related to Lewin's career. Included are agency contracts between Lewin and assorted representative agencies. Most of the contracts appear to be generic and very few include information about specific projects. Additionally, there are a small number of bulletins and rosters pertaining to the Writer's Guild of America strike in which it appears Lewin was involved in some capacity. There is no specific arrangement to the series.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Assorted contractual agreements with various agencies.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Bulletins concerning the strike and rosters of what appears to be picketer's names.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series contains a small number of letters to and from Lewin related to business and/or personal matters. It appears that Lewin may have considered some of the letters legal-type documents. Additionally, there are items involving Lewin and his longtime writing partner Burt Styler. The series is arranged alphabetically by folder titles which reflect the content of the folders.

did.unittitle: Al Lewin business and personal items

odd.head: General note
odd.p: With miscellaneous receipts that appear unrelated to correspondence.

did.unittitle: Famous Artists Corporation (letter to Charles Feldman from Lewin and Styler)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Appears to be related to professional dealings. With letter to and from Mickey Rooney regarding Blessed Events.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Some items in French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Printed Materials Series contains a small amount of press clippings related to Lewin and/or the projects he was involved in. There is no specific arrangement to the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Audio Recordings series is partially processed and contains cassette tapes and audio reel recordings of meetings and/or phone conversations which were recorded by Lewin. Many of these home recordings are labeled with dates and/or topic and are related to projects in which he was involved. There is no specific arrangement to the series. PLEASE NOTE: The sound recordings are restricted and use of the material requires production of listening copies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The 63rd Infantry Division Service Series contains materials related to Lewin's military service during World War II. Included are letters from fellow war veterans who served in the Division; a manuscript contrived by Pfc Alan Kellock; a photograph of the 63rd choir performing in Baton Rough, Louisiana; 10 copies of a newsletter contrived by Lewin; and a small number of Blood and Fire, a newspaper-like newsletter by and about the division. The series is arranged alphabetically by folder titles which reflect the content of the folders.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Folder originally titled Miscellaneous. Can Training Films be Used More Effectively in the Army manuscript by Pfc Alan Kellock, copies of newsletter contrived by Lewin, and letters from other members of Division. Also contains still of 63rd Infantry.

did.unittitle: Letters to and from Lewin with fellow war veterans from the 63rd Division

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Appears to be letters between Lewin and others who served in the 63rd Division during World War II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Esther Lewin papers contain a holograph manuscript of a publication entitled, Little Billy Boat, written by Esther Lewin, Albert Lewin's wife. Additionally, there is a press clipping of an interview with Mrs. Lewin from the mid-1940s.

did.unittitle: Little Billy Boat materials and press clipping

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Appears to be a holograph children's book manuscript with illustrations.
